data.title: Wimbledon news: Djokovic hit with big fine as Kyrgios accuses BBC commentator
data.meta_description: The latest and breaking news from Wimbledon after Carlos Alcaraz defeated Novak Djokovic to win the SW19 title.
data.text:
The latest and breaking news from Wimbledon after Carlos Alcaraz defeated Novak Djokovic to win the SW19 title.

By Jack McEachen

Link copied Bookmark

Carlos Alcaraz wins Wimbledon Gentlemen’s Singles title

A thrilling two weeks of Wimbledon have now come and gone as Carlos Alcaraz and Marketa Vondrousova have been crowned men's and women's singles champions, defeating Novak Djokovic and Ons Jabeur respectively. It was a tournament not without controversy, as we reflect and react on the third Grand Slam of the year.

Djokovic was denied his fifth consecutive SW19 title by the 20-year-old Spaniard in a five-setter that was of the highest quality, with the Centre Court crowd on their feet to welcome a new champion, Alcaraz's second Major already of his short career after winning last year's US Open.

Vondrousova was another first-time Wimbledon champion, having upset favourite Jabeur on Saturday in straight sets to become the first unseeded SW19 winner in the Open era - after brutally being dropped by Nike and forced to wear an unbranded kit.

Britain did have a champion in Henry Searle, as the 17-year-old broke the nation's 62-year duck to lift the boys' singles title on Sunday - becoming Britain's first junior champion since Laura Robson in 2008 while the last boy to lift the trophy was Sir Stanley Matthews' son of the same name in 1962.

Stay up to date with all the latest with Express Sport.

JUST IN Carlos Alcaraz's Wimbledon membership explained and Roger Federer mistake [LATEST]

Invalid email

We use your sign-up to provide content in ways you've consented to and to improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and 3rd parties based on our understanding. You can unsubscribe at any time. Read our Privacy Policy

1 year ago00:29 Danny Gallagher

Fritz fuming at the trolls

Taylor Fritz was gutted after his humiliating exit from Wimbledon, but little was the American to know that the misery would soon be compounded.

A cruel troll opted to mock the 25-year-old for failing at SW19, but was quickly met with a furious response.

Fritz took the troll on head-on as an argument erupted while streaming a video game online.

"'Finally back are you happy you lost?'" Fritz started by reading out a Twitch chat message, before giving an expletive-laden response to the fan.

FULL STORY.

1 year ago23:49 Danny Gallagher

Classy Novak

Despite the pain he must have felt when finally tasting defeat once again at Wimbledon, Novak Djokovic remained a man of his word.

During the tournament the Serbian ace had struck a deal with a journalist, and he went out of his way to ensure he came good on it.

FULL STORY.

1 year ago22:05 Danny Gallagher

When Roger met... Carlos

As Wimbledon celebrates a new champion, on what was his first ever final, Carlos Alcaraz is obviously the entire talk of SW19.

The dust will not settle for some time, as Sunday's final enters the history books as one of the most iconic showdowns in recent memory.

But it all has to start somewhere and, back in 2019, a rather unknown young Carlitos had the pleasure of sharing the court and hitting a few rallies with the great man himself.

Fans have taken to Twitter in the aftermath of his victory over Djokovic to share their accounts of the first time Alcaraz met Roger Federer.

1 year ago20:35 Danny Gallagher

Kyrgios drops 'freak remark'

It's very much like Nick Kyrgios to say things as he sees them.

So, of course, it was business as usual in the aftermath of Carlos Alcaraz's incredible, surging comeback victory over Djokovic to win the men's title.

Kyrgios immediately labelled Alcaraz a 'freak', meant in the most complimentary of ways... and even admitted it was the first time he had watched a full match of tennis in quite a considerable while.

He then made a specific point of thanking both players, showing a much softer and endearing side to his character.

FULL STORY.

1 year ago19:18 Danny Gallagher

Return of the GOAT?

Serena Williams has admitted a few times that she feels she still has much to give to tennis.

One of, if not the greatest female tennis player of all time, fans never get tired of clamouring for Serena to return.

Now however, it seems like she actually might.

Taking to Twitter, she opted to tell the world about a chance encounter in a book store, and how it seriously got her thinking.

FULL STORY.

1 year ago18:04 Danny Gallagher

The imitation game

One thing everybody can agree on is that the game plan of young Carlos Alcaraz at the All England Club was poetry in motion.

The Spaniard was a joy to behold, playing fizzing tennis from the off and keeping up a relentless pace throughout the tournament.

Even when he started very slowly indeed against Novak Djokovic in the final, the way he rapidly played himself back into contention was remarkable.

Everything about his approach was, however, very much copied. That is according to the youngster's coach Juan Carlos Ferrero, who has spoken out rather candidly about the new champion.

FULL STORY.

1 year ago17:00 Danny Gallagher

Djokovic slapped with fine

Just when Novak Djokovic perhaps though he couldn't feel any worse after losing the Wimbledon final, he's been hit with a meaty fine.

The defending champion produced a mid-match tantrum as the momentum started to sway over to Carlos Alcaraz on centre court, and he's not been allowed to get away from it.

Djokovic completely smashed his racket in anger, hitting the Wimbledon net on his way back to his seat.

Fans gasped in the stands, and the umpire and line judges looked far from impressed.

Now, the All England Club has promptly issued a fine in the multiple thousands.

FULL STORY.

1 year ago16:28 Danny Gallagher

Eubanks is flying

What a few weeks it has been for this fine gentleman.

The surprise package of Wimbledon, Chris Eubanks rapidly made his way into everyone's affections with his beautiful style of play and all-round personable charm.

Now, the world rankings are reflecting his endeavours splendidly.

He's climbed to a career-high 31st in Monday's updated world rankings, and he's above some huge names!

FULL STORY.

1 year ago15:15 Jack McEachen

Alcaraz drops trophy

Carlos Alcaraz has been appearing on TV stations across the world following his triumph over Novak Djokovic yesterday.

He has been parading the trophy around as is his right following a thrilling five-set victory, but not all went to plan when he dropped the gold prize.

He recovered well, however, as just the top of the lid including the golden pineapple temporarily came off.

You can read the full story HERE.

1 year ago14:37 Jack McEachen

Teen Brit champion to be fastracked

Wimbledon junior boys' champion Henry Searle will be "fast-tracked" into senior tournaments according to his coach Morgan Phillips.

The 17-year-old became the first British winner of the event in 62 years and has been tipped for a bright future, though he insisted he has to complete his A-Levels first.

"If you get top-10 then you get fast-tracked into some Challenger events - that's a big incentive for us," Phillips told the BBC. "Junior tennis is a massive platform going into the men's game.

That's what I've worked in for a good amount of years now - the transition from junior to men's and making them understand the big journey that's ahead.

"So there will be definitely an element of him going into the lower tier of professional tennis."

1 year ago14:05 Jack McEachen

Alcaraz the day after

Carlos Alcaraz has posted a heartwarming picture on social media the day after winning Wimbledon.

He has highlighted where he came from in a similar scene to the immediate reaction after defeating Novak Djokovic yesterday, going straight to his box to thank his team for their hard work.

Though the air that the new Wimbledon champion was getting as a child is seriously impressive...

1 year ago13:33 Jack McEachen

Becker disagrees with Djokovic

Boris Becker has challenged Novak Djokovic's claim that 2023 Wimbledon champion Carlos Alcaraz is a "complete" player.

The 20-year-old's abilities were clear for all to see on Sunday as he got the better of the defending champion, prompting Djokovic to be extremely complimentary of the new title holder.

"I haven't played a player like him ever, to be honest," he said. "Roger and Rafa obviously have their own strengths and weaknesses. Carlos is a very complete player. Amazing adapting capabilities that I think are a key for longevity and for a successful career on all surfaces."

Becker holds the opposite view, however, which you can read in full HERE.

1 year ago13:01 Jack McEachen

UFC star wins huge Alcaraz bet

UFC star Ilia Topuria made over £180,000 betting on his fellow Spaniard Carlos Alcaraz to win Wimbledon.

The 20-year-old defeated Novak Djokovic in a stunning five-setter to mark jubilant scenes back in Spain, but few compatriots will have been more delighted than Topuria.

Earlier this month, he bet $50,000 on Alcaraz to win the tournament - returning $237,500 (£181,415).

“My favorite tennis tournament Wimbledon begins,” Topuria said on Instagram when placing the bet, “And I've made my biggest bet to date. Carlos Alcaraz, to win! Let’s go, all the way with you!”

1 year ago12:24 Jack McEachen

Navratilova health update

Tennis icon Martina Navratilova has opened up on her "seven months of hell" before being declared cancer-free last month.

The nine-time Wimbledon singles champion was present at SW19 throughout the tournament and enjoyed Carlos Alcaraz's final win from the Royal Box.

She spoke to Good Morning Britain on Monday to discuss her road to recovery after breast and throat cancer left her with "seven months of hell, emotionally and physically."

She praised her wife Julia Lemigova who "was amazing," Navratilova said. "Helping me throughout the treatment. Particularly in New York with the seven weeks of proton.

"So I was diagnosed early December and I finally got the all-clear three weeks ago. So it really has been seven months of hell, emotionally and physically.

"I lost about 25lbs so I'm very slender now. It's been very difficult but I'm cancer free now knock on wood. And Julia - it scared her too. it was scary.

"The actual treatment was horrific. You know chemotherapy, radiation, it really beat me up. Physically it was brutal and it's still hanging over your shoulder. No matter what you can't get away from it. We were both really scared."

1 year ago11:52 Jack McEachen

Alcaraz's social media boom

Carlos Alcaraz has seen his social media explode after winning his first Wimbledon title on Sunday.

His five-set victory over Novak Djokovic saw the Spaniard gain over 530,000 Instagram followers in a single day.

Alcaraz's new fans will have seen him claim that winning Wimbledon ensured that "everything is happening too fast" on social media but he took the time to thank those that supported him on his journey.

"A lifelong dream!" Alcaraz wrote on Instagram. "You always have to believe! I'm only 20 years old, everything is happening too fast, but I'm very proud of how we work every day. Thank you everyone for your support, from the bottom of my heart! @wimbledon."

1 year ago11:18 Jack McEachen

BBC viewing figures

Viewing figures that are emerging from the BBC have seen yesterday's final reach a huge audience, eclipsing the days when Roger Federer was competing for titles.

Both men's and women's finals numbers are up dramatically from 2022 as fans have responded to see new names on the title.

Carlos Alcaraz's victory over Novak Djokovic was watched by a reported 11m peak audience, with even more following online.

You can read the full story HERE.

1 year ago10:25 Jack McEachen

Rankings update

Following his first Wimbledon title, Carlos Alcaraz remains world No 1 in the ATP rankings, as Novak Djokovic and Daniil Medvedev both could have usurped the Spaniard.

He has an 880-point lead over second-placed Djokovic, while the top 10 remain the same - but Americans Tommy Paul and Christopher Eubanks moved up to world No 14 and 31 respectively, both career-highs.

Women's singles champion Marketa Vondrousova cracked the WTA's top 10 for the first time as she sits 10th.

Iga Swiatek remains at the top of the rankings despite her quarter-final exit to Ukrainian Elina Svitolina, who herself jumps up to No 27 just a few months after rejoining the tour.

1 year ago09:48 Jack McEachen

Djokovic spotted eating banana skin

BBC viewers believe that they have spotted Novak Djokovic eating the skin of a banana during the Wimbledon final.

Bananas are often consumed by athletes but the skin usually remains intact, the Serb has been accused of making an exception on Centre Court.

Djokovic has been a man of mystery at times with the patch he wears on his chest and rumours of a 'magic potion' he drinks, but fans have been perplexed this time.

You can read the full story HERE.

1 year ago09:09 Jack McEachen

Djokovic and Alcaraz the next rivalry

Laura Robson has claimed that Novak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz have the potential to be the next big rivalry in tennis after their epic final.

The Spaniard won on this occasion to take revenge for the French Open semi-final he lost after suffering from nervousness-induced cramps, but Robson has claimed that if Djokovic continues playing then they can become huge rivals.

“I’d love it to develop into a bit of a rivalry," Robson told Eurosport. "Obviously, there’s a bit of an age gap, but Djokovic has been so healthy the last few years, playing better tennis than ever.

"Coming into the tournament, and especially in the whole of 2023, he played the best in the world across the level at the events he played.

“It definitely has potential as a rivalry, but we don’t want to go too soon on it yet because fingers crossed they stay healthy enough to play matches like the top guys have for the last 15 years.”

1 year ago08:37 Jack McEachen

Djokovic to face snub

Novak Djokovic is set to be snubbed by the Wimbledon chiefs in a further blow having lost his title at SW19.

The Serb complained throughout the tournament at the 11.00pm curfew that forced himself and several other high-profile games to be played over two days.

However, the All England Club is set to reject any calls for games to start earlier on Centre Court or for the curfew to be extended.

You can read the full story HERE.

1 year ago08:07 Jack McEachen

Prince Louis wants Wimbledon role

Prince Louis was reportedly 'very upset' that he was not able to attend yesterday's thrilling final between Novak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz - but the Wimbledon grounds could be seeing a lot more of the Royal.

The Princess of Wales has claimed that Louis wants to be a ballboy in the future, in a chat with the talented team at SW19.

According to PA Sport, Kate told 16-year-old ballboy Joel that Louis had even been practicing. “He (Louis) tries to practise the standing and staying serious like us," he claimed Kate said.

“He tries to practise the stands and how we stand at the back of the court and next to the players.”

1 year ago07:36 Jack McEachen

Alcaraz and Djokovic request

Centre Court were treated to a high-level battle between Novak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz yesterday, as the young Spaniard brought an end to Djokovic's dominance at Wimbledon.

The 36-year-old has at times appeared unbeatable in SW19 and seemingly keeps improving with age, but tennis icon Mats Wilander hopes that the Serb continues in order to see more clashes against Alcaraz in the future.

“I would love to see Novak stay in our sport for another three, four years if he can, just so I can see this match again," Wilander told Eurosport. "I wish Novak was 10 years younger, because then we would see this rivalry for another 10 years.

“There’s a contrast of styles between these two, even though they’re both baseliners. Carlos Alcaraz has so much flair and so much explosiveness in his arm, and he can hit these forehands and then can massage these little drop shots."

1 year ago07:32 Jack McEachen

Djokovic refuses to apologise

Novak Djokovic burst into a fit of rage as his reign as defending champion was coming to an end in a fifth set against Carlos Alcaraz on Sunday.

After losing a crucial point, he threw his racket at the Wimbledon net and left a mark on the post.

BBC commentator Andrew Castle felt that he should have auctioned off the racket but instead gave it to a member of the crowd as a souvenir, though he refused to apologise for his actions.

You can read the full story HERE.

1 year ago07:29 Jack McEachen

Kyrgios accuses commentator

Nick Kyrgios was forced to sit out of this year's Wimbledon owing to injury concerns, but had his say during the final as he called out the BBC.

The Australian finished last year as runner-up to Novak Djokovic in SW19 but was not happy with the commentators that the Beeb provided to cover the match.

He was not the only one, as numerous viewers made complaints over the lack of John McEnroe as Andrew Castle, Tim Henman and Pat Cash provided the commentary for yesterday's final.

You can read the full story HERE.

1 year ago07:27 Jack McEachen

Good morning

Hello and welcome to Express Sport's live coverage of Wimbledon, as we look back on an enthralling two weeks and follow the reaction to Carlos Alcaraz becoming champion.
